property.description:
EMC VMAX (formerly Symmetrix) is the original storage platform - the platform that revolutionized the storage industry and has proven its reputation as the gold standard for high-end storage.

The Symmetrix VMAX integrates with virtual server environments with its scale-out architecture and software that optimize provisioning for VMware and Hyper-V virtual machines.

Summarizes how capacity is utilized.
  • Primary Used:Array capacity that has been mapped, masked, and configured for the primary storage of application data. This does not include copies.
  • Local Replica Used: Array capacity that has been mapped, masked, and configured as local replicas. This capacity is commonly used for testing and backup.
  • Remote Replica Used: Array capacity that has been mapped, masked, and configured for remote copies. This capacity is commonly used for disaster recovery.
  • System Used: Capacity reserved for use by the array for internal operations.
If columns date to 100% or time to 100% are empty, it simply means that the value won't be reach in the next 180 days

property.description: Represent the entire System/Storage Bay Symmetrix VMAX
Hardware storage component from which you can read and write data.

The component in the Symmetrix system that supports front end, back end, and SRDF connections, and also provides physical memory, connection to the virtualmatrix, and connection to Back-End I/O Modules

The component in the Symmetrix system that supports front end, back end, and SRDF connections, and also provides physical memory, connection to the virtualmatrix, and connection to Back-End I/O Modules

A uniquely addressable part of the Symmetrix subsystem that consists of a set of access arms, the associated disk surfaces, and the electronic circuitry required to locate, read, and write data. A logical unit of storage defined within a Symmetrix array.

Thin devices for Virtual Provisioning are devices that do not have storage allocated to them when they are created. Thin devices can be created with an inflated capacity, because the actual storage space for the data written to the thin devices is on the DATA devices.To a host operating system, they look like regular devices with their configured capacity. The host treats them as regular devices and writes and reads from these devices like regular devices.

Allows individual devices to be concatenated to create larger devices. A metadevice consists of a metahead and its member devices. The metahead is the first device in the metadevice sequence and is responsible for receiving all incoming commands. It also identifies the entire metadevice. When an incoming command for the metahead is processed, the Symmetrix determines which metadevice member should execute the command. Metahead devices can be added to a device group while a metamember cannot be added to a device group. This holds true for both standard and BCV devices.

Thin devices for Virtual Provisioning are devices that do not have storage allocated to them when they are created. Thin devices can be created with an inflated capacity, because the actual storage space for the data written to the thin devices is on the DATA devices.To a host operating system, they look like regular devices with their configured capacity. The host treats them as regular devices and writes and reads from these devices like regular devices.
Virtual Device (VDEV) is a host-addressable Symmetrix device with special attributes created at configuration time.
Interface device between the storage system and other computers or peripheral devices. Also, an interface between a drive and bus.
A logical association of between 2 to 16 drives with the same RAID level

property.description: A logical construct of drives supporting both read and write data accesses.
A storage group is a logical grouping of up to 4,096 Symmetrix devices. Both thick and thin LUNs can be used.

• Configured Usable:Sum of all thick devices (including standard, BCV and R1 devices) plus the sum of all data devices (pool storage).
  • Hot Spares:Sum of disks dedicated as hot spares
  • RAID overhead:Array capacity used to support RAID protection overhead.
  • Unconfigured:Sum of free column of the symdisk list command
  • Unusable:Sum of unusable capacity in the form of small fragments that were the result of configuration and provisioning operations.
Note: Sum of all 5 might not exactly match the Raw capacity, because of rounding used, failed disks, etc.
Sum of all thick devices (including standard, BCV and R1 devices) plus the sum of all data devices (pool storage).
Sum of disks dedicated as hot spares
Array capacity used to support RAID protection overhead.
Sum of all thick devices (including standard, BCV and R1 devices) plus the sum of all data devices (pool storage).
Any unusable capacity due to small fragments or disk fragmentation and disabled portion of short-stroked drives.

• Free:Sum of Unbound Data Devices, Unbound Save Devices, and Unused Luns.
  • Pool Free: Unwritten space within thin pool and snap pool.
  • Used by Block: Capacity that is made available to storage area network (SAN).
Unbound Data and SAVE devices, and unmapped and unmasked thick LUNs.
Unwritten space within pools and unbound capacity within RAID Groups.
Capacity that is made available to storage area network (SAN).
Capacity that is made available to network attached storage (NAS).

Summarizes how capacity is utilized.
  • Primary Used:Array capacity that has been mapped, masked, and configured for the primary storage of application data. This does not include copies.
  • Local Replica Used: Array capacity that has been mapped, masked, and configured as local replicas. This capacity is commonly used for testing and backup.
  • Remote Replica Used: Array capacity that has been mapped, masked, and configured for remote copies. This capacity is commonly used for disaster recovery.
  • System Used: Capacity reserved for use by the array for internal operations.
